reviewText: Jean Harlow was one of the great screen comediennes and she was blessed with considerable comedic timing. This ability is shown to perfection is this extremely funny 1934 film. Though made one year after the restrictive Hayes Office banned all inneuendo in films, this movie manages to revolve around the subject of "having fun" with your dating partner before marriage. Harlow is paired with the underrated Franchot Tone, who was at his apex of fame here, and then sadly was reduced to playing in supporting roles, then ultimately bit parts in B movies. But Tone effortlessly captures the mood of the piece and excels in the role of besotted playboy. The magnificent Lionel Barrymore plays the crabby father of Tone and who is also Harlow's initial love interest. Yes, you read it right, Lionel Barrymore plays (for a little while) a ladies man. That is a first for him.There are enough witty moments to keep you interested and Harlow always glows with a unique screen charisma. Though predictable in its twists and turns, it still rivets the viewer, all these years later. The only flaw is that movie is a scant 72 minutes in length, one wishes it could have continued for another half hour. This is a great old movie which has held up marvelously. If you've never had the pleasure of watching Harlow, this would be an excellent first choice to sample her magic.
Title: N/A

reviewText: --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------"The Girl From Missouri"(Warner Brother, 1934)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The voluptuous Jean Harlowe stars in this still-scandalous Depression-era comedy about a poor, working class girl who tries to land a rich husband while still retaining her virtue (ie: flirting but not sleeping with her sugar daddies). The premise will seem strange to many modern viewers in an era when women have so many more life choices, but even so you may be amazed at how raw and sexually blunt this old film can be: you have to read between the lines, but not too far, as the movie pretty much puts it all on the line. Economic hardships and social hypocrisies are laid bare, as are many a néglige. Connoisseurs of pre-Code Hollywood films will delight in this movie, but may be surprised that it actually passed the censors in '34 -- and Harlowe fans will be in heaven watching her in one of her most complex dramatic roles. A doozy of an oldie, thankfully saved from the vaults! (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue film reviews)

reviewText: Eadie Chapman (Jean Harlow) comes from a hard-scrabble background. Her deceased father was a drunk, and her mother was forced to trade her self-respect to survive, a social status little improved when she married a second husband who is no better than a pimp. He is the purveyor of a sleazy dance hall where the female employees are expected to offer male customers much more than a few casual dances. Eadie loves her mother, but she is determined not to be dragged down to her mother's level. Eadie realizes with clear-eyed pragmatism that the only way to improve her situation in life is to hold onto her virtue and marry a respectable man--ideally a very rich man, who can give her a life of ease and security.At the start of the movie, Eadie and her best friend Kitty (Patsy Kelly, best known forPlease Don't Eat the Daisies) hop a train for New York City, the land of millionaires. Once there, they get jobs as chorus girls off-Broadway. As a beautiful, young, platinum-blonde, Eadie is forced to constantly fend off unwanted male advances, and her boss is one of the worst offenders. When she hears that a troupe of her fellow hoofers have been hired as the entertainment for a private, penthouse party, she is determined to go so that she can finally have a chance to meet rich men. Her boss allows her to join the group only if she will promise to finally go out on a date with him. Thus begins Kitty's misadventures with the rich and powerful.This movie is packed with talent and star power. Anita Loos (Gentlemen Prefer Blondes) is co-screenwriter, and the script is terrific. Nowadays we'd call a film like this a "dramedy," as it is equal parts drama and comedy.Jean Harlow does a fabulous job. She is justly famous as a comedic actress, and she is also a wonderful dramatic actress. She began her film career at the tender age of 16. She played often uncredited bit parts until she got her big break in 1930 in the Howard Hughes World War I epic, Hell's Angels. Hughes sold her contract to MGM, and the next year her role inPlatinum Blondelaunched her into the stratosphere as an adored sex goddess. By the time this particular film was made in 1934, she was still only 23, but she had already made many films with some of the biggest male stars of the era.Lionel Barrymore plays unmarried (presumably widowed) cut-throat millionaire T.R. Paige. He was 56 at the time of this film, and is a very different kind of antagonist in this film than the villain he played 12 years later as the evil Mr. Potter inIt's A Wonderful Life. T. R. Paige is a fascinating mix of good and bad, because his favorite saying might be, "Payback is a bitch." In the midst of one of his business paybacks early on in the film, he serves as an unexpectedly gallant ally to Eadie. But late in the movie, he proves to be an equally dangerous enemy, when he concludes that Eadie is not good enough for his handsome, playboy son, T.R. Paige Jr. (Franchot Tone, best known for his Academy-Award-nominated role inMutiny on the Bounty).Franchot Tone was 29 at the time of this film, and a year away from his marriage to Joan Crawford. He made three other movies with Jean Harlow and was an extremely successful romantic, leading man who later moved beyond that into more serious dramatic roles.Patsy Kelly had one of the biggest roles of her career as a character actress in this film. She's a terrific comic actress, and she does a wonderful job in this film as Eadie's man-crazy best friend whom Eadie has, with comic irony, chosen to be her chaperone in her pursuit of respectability and a rich husband.A familiar face in the movie is Paige Sr.'s personal assistant, Miss Newberry, played by Clara Blandick, a popular supporting actress of the era. Her  most famous role is Auntie Em inThe Wizard of Oz, and she also played Aunt Polly in the Tom Sawyer film of 1930 and the Huckleberry Finn movie of 1931.I see similar plotting elements of this story in the 1957 romantic comedy film,How To Marry A Millionaire, though that film is pure comedy. Anyone who enjoyed HTMAM, will very likely be pleased with this movie, as well.This film includes a startling amount of subject matter that is in direct violation of the Motion Picture Production Code of 1930 (the Hays Code), in particular: "The sanctity of the institution of marriage and the home shall be upheld. Pictures shall not infer that low forms of sex relationship are the accepted or common thing." This film appears, on the surface, to violate that stricture, because there are a lot of male characters constantly trying to take advantage of young, attractive women. Possibly, though, the film's moral auditors ultimately deemed it acceptable because it could be viewed as a kind of morality play. In spite of constant temptations to "go bad," and the overwhelming pull of her own mother's example, the heroine faithfully attempts to remain a "good girl." The film also repeatedly makes plain, in keeping with the morality and gender-role stereotypes of its era, that the only secure, socially acceptable choice for a young woman is marriage. (Also in keeping with the double standard of the day, the possibility of finding a potential spouse who is capable of fidelity and also makes an excellent living is presented as a lovely fairy tale.)This is a fun movie, if you can accept it as a product of its times with the heavy burdens of sexism all such films contain. Also, anyone who wishes to discover the work of the legendary Jean Harlowe, and who also enjoys romantic comedy, would be well advised to begin with this movie.
summary: Jean Harlow, age 23, at the height of her career, three years before her untimely death

reviewText: THE GIRL FROM MISSOURI is a surprisingly good movie. It is a comedy which allows Jean Harlow to show her versatility as an actress. The story is about a girl who sets out deliberately to marry a rich man. Harlow is backed by a superb cast which includes Lionel Barrymore, Franchot Tone, Lewis Stone, Patsy Kelly and Alan Mowbray.Anita Loos was the screenwriter. Jack Conway replaced Sam Wood as director during the production of the film. Conway also directed A TALE OF TWO CITIES (1935) and SARATOGA (1937).
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sam Wood is the director of THE GIRL FROM MISSOURI but this movie so thoroughly marked an "Anita Loos film".  The legendary comic author/screenwriter never had a better actress for her stories than the beautiful, talented and totally endearing Jean Harlow and the Harlow/Loos combo whipped up a number of classic motion pictures.  MISSOURI is one of the less known of the bunch but it's a fine comedy of a sexy gal from the wrong side of the tracks who is bound and determined to land a rich husband but all she seems to land is trouble.  The influence of Loos' famous novel GENTLEMEN PREFER BLONDES is unmistakable on this original screenplay right down to having the brunette sex-obsessed (as opposed to money-obsessed) best friend.  Lots of laughs in this one.
summary: Delightful Jean Harlow Vehicle by Anita Loos
